title: Agents and Editors: Should novel manuscripts submitted by new authors have a table of contents? - Quora

response.answer_text: It would highly unusual for a novel to have a table of contents. TOC’s are reserved for non-fiction work. The inherent structure of the story should enable the reader to smoothly move through the work. However, your fictional submission should include a strong summary or description of the story in the cover letter, usually no more than a single page. Think jacket copy. If a novel s very complex with many characters or intricate timelines, sometimes an author will include a cast of characters or a timeline. Authorlink®

Novels? Usually, no. If you’ve done something clever like written a poem where each line is a chapter title, maybe —but even then, I think it would be more fun to see whether the editor noticed what you’d done. If the chapters are just numbered, then no, don’t provide a table of contents.

No, because often editors will suggest or require changes that would result in material being moved to different chapters or deleted. It’s best to wait until all editorial changes are finalized before preparing a table of contents.

The purpose of a TOC, is to allow your reader a shortcut to look up specific things in the book. For example, you might have a book about COVID; one reader wants to know about treatments, another wants to know about prevention, another about WHO stats. So you have a TOC to point out each chapter. None of that is necessary (or even particularly useful) with a novel.
If it is non-fiction, yes. If it is fiction, no need unless you give each chapter a name/title, which isn’t that common these days.
